Six states have sued TRW Inc., contending that its credit-rating subsidiary secretly judged consumers on their bill-paying ability and sold confidential information from its data base on 170 million Americans.

"TRW is masquerading as a mere library of credit histories, when in fact it is secretly rating the creditworthiness of consumers," Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said yesterday. "TRW has a legal obligation to disclose to consumers its true role in the credit-granting process."

Mr. Abrams's suit, filed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, also charged the Cleveland-based TRW with failing to maintain reasonable procedures to assure the accuracy of its reports.
A second suit, also announced yesterday, was filed in Texas on Monday by attorneys general from Alabama, California, Idaho, Michigan and Texas.
A TRW spokeswoman said the company would comment on the legal actions later.
TRW, according to the New York suit, receives about 500,000 complaints a year involving supposed inaccuracies in its reports.
The suit asks the court to order TRW to stop breaking the law, and it seeks an unspecified amount of penalties, restitution and damages.
Mr. Abrams said TRW had misled consumers by telling them it merely gathered information about individuals from creditors like banks, retailers and financial service companies.
But the Attorney General contended that the agency secretly rated and evaluated consumers for their ability to pay bills.
Unknown to consumers, the suit said, TRW offers its subscribers, for an additional fee, point-scoring systems that rate an individual's creditworthiness according to a variety of factors.

Also unknown to consumers, the suit said, TRW issues one version of a consumer's credit report to subscribers and another to the consumer. The version that goes to subscribers has an easy-to-read summary and, in some cases, credit-scoring information.

Consumers do not receive a summary or the scoring information, making the report difficult to understand, the suit contended. More than 170 different codes, abbreviations and symbols may be used in a report.
